Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code for the core module half-finished. As an engineer, I knew everyone was waiting on me—the project couldn’t move forward until I delivered. The pressure was suffocating, but every time I tried to focus, the memory of the heated argument with my teammates replayed in my mind. The conflict had left us barely speaking, and now, collaboration was impossible. As a mentee, I was supposed to reach out to my mentor, to be open about challenges like this. But I hesitated. Would admitting the team was falling apart make me look incompetent? Would my mentor think I couldn’t handle pressure? Yet, if I stayed silent, the project would stall, and I’d let everyone down as an engineer. My inbox pinged with another reminder from the project manager. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between writing code and drafting an honest message to my mentor, the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
